This class is mandatory for first-year students, which I don't see any necessity. Some invited speakers has totally different research areas from my interest. I don't have any interest in their research areas, and I feel like I'm wasting my life in listening to their talk.
Great introduction to topics in Public health.
Widened my view on relevant topics.
informative seminars. great food.
We had the unique opportunity to learn about a wide range of topics pertaining to chronic disease epidemiology.
the structure was not very much clear, so I am kind of confused at the connection between each sections in the same lecture in the beginning
The different presentations were interesting

I have enjoyed the speakers so far. All of the topics have been engaging and I enjoy the variety as well. Check-in/lunch is the one area that I think could be improved. If we had everything set up about 10 minutes earlier, that may help to streamline the process. I remember one day a good number of students had arrived early and sat down, but the sign-in/food were not available. Then we had to exit the room to get into the line for food and sign-in which took 10 minutes or so. Otherwise, I think everything is working well!
Interesting seminar topics
A very good chance to know the frontiers of public health.

I enjoyed the CDE seminar series this semester. I appreciate that Dr. Hawley encouraged students to recommended speakers/topic areas. My only criticism is that I wish that we had more frequent speaker sessions. I think we had 3-4 speakers this semester, and I would have loved the opportunity to attend more!

The talks were very interesting overall though I feel that there was a bit more focus on basic science or biological determinants of health. There should be more focus on social determinants of health and how those intersect with chronic diseases. I think conversations on social determinants of health are very important in public health.

I found some of the speakers inaccessible in how in-depth they went into their topics. I was unable to follow some of the seminars. I really enjoyed the gun violence seminar because it was not too in depth, it was very interesting, and easy to follow.
nice speakers with diverse topics
Wonderful discussions of important topics in PH
Good. We got to know the research topics better.
Excellent variety of speakers to learn about different public health issues
Interesting speakers
I think it's an interesting introduction to topics in chronic disease epidemiology. I think increased time for questions/discussion might allow for more engagement with the presentatios.
full score.

The course is a general introduction of epidemiology, it is essential for us beginners. The basic concepts, study methods in class could guide us the way for further study. But the exams might be a little bit rigorous, emphasize much on distinguishing concepts(different study design) or using the formula, I would prefer to spend more time doing homework or reading some contemporary articles in this area instead of spending much time preparing for exams.
great introduction to the work being done by YSPH and other relevant research in the field

Strengths - great for providing a range of topics in CDE, very insightful 
Weaknesses - potentially have speakers with more corporate focus
Interesting lectures. Would love it if we could get more/better food!
Overall, I loved the course. I was sad that some of the talks were cancelled, but I'm hoping they can be rescheduled in the spring! Loved the diversity in topics.
The CDE seminar guest lecturers are always fascinating and relevant!
Nicky is great. I love her sense of style!
Great introductions.
Very responsive and helpful
Professor Hawley did a truly terrific job organizing and running this seminar series.
Great speaker choices!
Dr. Hawley did a great job organizing the series. She mainly presented speakers, so I don't have much more to say about strengths and weaknesses.

Nicky is organized and seems receptive to feedback from students and everyone else. She created a very warm and welcoming atmosphere in the room for everyone regardless of their departmental affiliation to participate.
Very approachable and engages us in discussion during/after the presentations.
Dr. Hawley chose strong speakers with diverse academic interests, and was always open to suggestions from students. Great instructor.
enthusiatic

Professor Nicola has a broad knowledge in epidemiology, while sometimes, epidemiology may contain some basic mechanism in pathophysiology, which professor could have a better preparation if she spends a bit more in understanding the diseases.
so wonderful!
Great!
She does a good job organizing all of these lectures!
Very good organizer!
Professor Hawley is able to create an engaging environment and brings in fascinating speaker!
It's a great non-credit course!
Worth taking
I would recommend that these seminars should be held more regularly if the budget permits.
This class is a foundation for public health and it is very important. So I would recommend the class to another student, and encourage them to spend more time on the class materials.
It was fine and it is a required course
Presentations on a variety of topic within chronic disease epidemiology. I would recommend this to another student interested in CDE!
A good way to know other scientists' research.
The seminar series is an opportunity to gain insight into research on chronic diseases and is especially useful for gaining exposure to research areas you are likely not familiar with.
Great seminar overall! Relevant for people interested in chronic diseases and would like to learn about the biological determinants of health.
This course introduced several popular topics concerning chronic disease research. It is a good opportunity to explore research interest.
Great seminar series with speakers from different research interests, Very interested and would suggest it.
It's a neat introduction to diverse research topics across the CDE field. Would recommend to another student.
Yes, this is the basis for our future learning in public health. It is right to set this course as a core lesson, and I would recommend the other students to take this course.
I would highly recommend this seminar! It is great for giving insight into the different areas of chronic disease epidemiology and different research happening in the field.

Its a good way to broaden the horizons. It would be better comprehensived if the articles were read in advance. Group disccusion before the seminars might be helpful. I would recommend it if students are interested in chronic diseases epidemiology research.
Even though mandatory, the course never felt like it was simply a requirement. The speakers were amazing and their topics were diverse. Really looking forward to the Spring!
An hour well-spent every few weeks!
